structured_data.name: Global Drought Narrative
structured_data.description: A monthly narrative on the state of global drought provided by the National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI).
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Monthly, with data available from 1997 to 2025 (as indicated by year selection options)

structured_data.method_of_access: View all notes, Copy link, Share Buttons
structured_data.description: The document is a webpage from tandfonline.com, likely an academic publication. It includes options for sharing and privacy settings. No specific dataset is described within the provided content.

structured_data.name: Global high-resolution drought indices for 1981–2022
structured_data.method_of_access: Publicly available at the Centre for Environmental Data Analysis (CEDA) via a DOI link.
structured_data.description: This dataset provides four high-resolution (5 km) gridded drought records based on the standardized precipitation evaporation index (SPEI) covering the period 1981–2022. These multi-scale (1–48 months) SPEI indices are computed based on monthly precipitation from CHIRPS and MSWEP, and potential evapotranspiration from GLEAM and hPET. The datasets are provided by Solomon H. Gebrechorkos et al. and are publicly available at CEDA.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: 1981–2022 (monthly indices with multi-year drought frequency analysis)

structured_data.name: Global Precipitation Climatology Centre (GPCC)
structured_data.description: GPCC Global Precipitation Climatology Centre monthly precipitation dataset from 1901-present is calculated from global station data.

structured_data.name: Global Drought Conditions (3-month SPI ERA5, 9-month SPI GPCC, Vegetation Health Index)
structured_data.description: This page provides maps, tools, and resources addressing drought conditions around the world. It includes a 3-month Standardized Precipitation Index (SPI) from the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECWMF) Reanalysis Version 5 (ERA5), a 9-month SPI from the Global Precipitation Climatology Centre (GPCC), and a Vegetation Health Index. ERA5 data combines historical observations into global estimates from 1940–present. GPCC data is calculated from global station data from 1901–present. The Vegetation Health Index characterizes vegetation health or combined moisture and thermal conditions, often used for crop condition and anticipated yield.

structured_data.name: Global Drought Narrative
structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface query and access to monthly reports via links
structured_data.description: A monthly narrative on the state of global drought provided by NOAA NCEI. The report covers global drought conditions for April 2022, with access to previous and subsequent months in 2022, 2023, 2024, and 2025.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Monthly, specifically April 2022, with reports available for 2022-2025

structured_data.name: Rainfall estimates (CHIRPS)
structured_data.method_of_access: Accessed through DE Africa’s Open Data Cube, DE Africa Map, and Jupyter Notebooks. Raw data available via CHIRPS monthly and daily data links.
structured_data.description: The Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation with Station data (CHIRPS) provides monthly and daily rainfall estimates. Produced by the Climate Hazards Center in collaboration with the US Geological Survey, it uses rain gauge and satellite observations. The dataset is regularly indexed to DE Africa and covers from 1981 to present, with daily and monthly updates respectively.

structured_data.name: Precipitation - CMORPH CDR
structured_data.description: The Satellite Precipitation - CMORPH Climate Data Record (CDR) consists of satellite precipitation estimates that have been bias corrected and reprocessed using the Climate Prediction Center (CPC) Morphing Technique (MORPH) to form a global, high resolution precipitation analysis. Provided by NOAA NCEI.

structured_data.name: Definition of Drought
structured_data.description: This page from NOAA's National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI) provides information related to the definition of drought.

structured_data.name: Global Historical Climatology Network daily (GHCNd)
structured_data.method_of_access: HTTPS, Climate Data Online, direct email contact for off-line availability
structured_data.data_format: ASCII (plain text) files, GZIP-compressed TAR file
structured_data.description: The Global Historical Climatology Network daily (GHCNd) is an integrated database of daily climate summaries from land surface stations across the globe, provided by NCEI. It contains records from more than 100,000 stations in 180 countries and territories, with daily variables including maximum and minimum temperature, total daily precipitation, snowfall, and snow depth. Record length and period of record vary by station, ranging from less than a year to more than 175 years. The dataset receives daily updates and is reconstructed each weekend.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: Station-level data from over 100,000 stations globally
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Varies by station, from less than a year to more than 175 years; daily updates

structured_data.name: Drought Indicators
structured_data.description: The European and Global Drought Observatories (EDO/GDO) produce continuously updated drought indicators. These indicators represent statistical anomalies of the current situation with respect to the long-term average, covering various components of the hydrological cycle and specific impacts. They are available at scales varying between 5 by 5 kilometers to 1 decimal degree (+/- 100 kilometers). The indicators include Standardized Precipitation Index (SPI), Soil Moisture Anomaly (SMA), Anomaly of Vegetation Condition (FAPAR Anomaly), Low-Flow Index (LFI, for Europe), Heat and Cold Wave Index (HCWI), Combined Drought Indicator (CDI, for Europe), Risk of Drought Impact for Agriculture (RDrI-Agri, Global), and Indicator for Forecasting Unusually Wet and Dry Conditions (Global).

structured_data.name: Drought
structured_data.description: A drought is defined as a period of abnormally dry weather characterized by a prolonged deficiency of precipitation below a certain threshold over a large area and a period longer than a month. It is a complex, slow-onset phenomenon with various types (meteorological, hydrological, agricultural, socioeconomic) and impacts across sectors. The World Meteorological Organization (WMO)'s Handbook of Drought Indicators and Indices provides a compendium of commonly used drought indicators/indices.

structured_data.name: Temperature and precipitation gridded data for global and regional domains derived from in-situ and satellite observations
structured_data.description: This dataset provides high-resolution gridded temperature and precipitation observations from a selection of sources, including GISTEMP, Berkeley Earth, CPC and CPC-CONUS. It also contains daily global average near-surface temperature anomalies. All fields are defined on either daily or monthly frequency. The datasets are regularly updated to incorporate recent observations. Provided by Copernicus.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Daily or monthly frequency, regularly updated

structured_data.name: PERSIANN-CDR: Precipitation Estimation from Remotely Sensed Information using Artificial Neural Networks - Climate Data Record
structured_data.method_of_access: Direct download via FTP, web interface for visualization, subsetting, and download
structured_data.description: The Precipitation Estimation from Remotely Sensed Information using Artificial Neural Networks- Climate Data Record (PERSIANN-CDR) provides daily rainfall estimates at a spatial resolution of 0.25 degrees in the latitude band 60S - 60N from 1983 to the near-present. It is produced using the PERSIANN algorithm on GridSat-B1 infrared satellite data, trained with NCEP stage IV hourly precipitation data, and adjusted using the Global Precipitation Climatology Project (GPCP) monthly product version 2.2. It is a consistent, long-term dataset with over 30 years of data, updated quarterly, and intended for climatological studies of the hydrological component of the climate system.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: 1983 to near-present (updated quarterly), daily temporal resolution

structured_data.name: Drought Monitoring & Soil Moisture
structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface with links to images and data files
structured_data.description: This section from the NOAA Climate Prediction Center's Monitoring and Data Index provides various drought-related products, including current and archived Palmer Drought Severity Index maps, Palmer Drought Severity Index Percentiles maps (by Climate Divisions and by State), additional precipitation needed to bring Palmer Index to -0.5 Inches, Current Crop Moisture Index maps, and Palmer Drought Severity & Crop Moisture Indices Data for current and past 3 weeks. It also includes Topsoil Moisture Monitoring and GIS Data.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: Global (implied by 'Global' country context, though specific maps show US regions)
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Current and last 3 weeks (for some data), archives available

structured_data.name: TerraClimate: Global, high-resolution gridded temperature, precipitation, and other water balance variables
structured_data.method_of_access: Direct download via THREDDS server, direct download selectable by variable and year, online visualization tool, point data download tool
structured_data.description: TerraClimate is a global gridded dataset of meteorological and water balance variables for 1958-present, available on a monthly timestep. It combines spatial climatology from WorldClim with time-varying information from CRU TS4.0. In addition to maximum and minimum temperatures and precipitation, it provides derived variables including reference evapotranspiration, vapor pressure deficit, and PDSI, as well as water balance metrics like runoff, snow water equivalent, soil moisture, and climatic water deficit. The dataset is provided by UCAR and developed by Dr. John Abatzoglou.

structured_data.name: GDO Standardized Precipitation Index ERA5, 48-month accumulation period (SPI-48) (version 2.0.0)
structured_data.method_of_access: Data Download Service (NetCDF, GeoTIFF), Downloadable PDF (Factsheet)
structured_data.description: The 48-month Standardized Precipitation Index (SPI-48) is a meteorological drought indicator to monitor precipitation anomalies over 48-month accumulation periods, serving as a proxy for long-term impacts like reduced reservoir and groundwater recharge. It is derived from the ECMWF ERA5 hourly precipitation data, using a reference period between 1991 and 2020. The SPI represents precipitation anomalies as deviations from the long-term mean in a standard-normal distribution. Provided by European Commission, Joint Research Centre (JRC). Updated monthly.

decision_log.summary: CCRA plan for hazards/drought (Global) with 90 structured queries.

queries_processed: Dry spell duration frequency global map

decision_log.summary: This batch of documents is highly promising for drought hazard data. Several NOAA and Copernicus links point directly to global drought monitoring reports and high-resolution gridded datasets, including SPEI and precipitation data. The Earth System Science Data article is particularly relevant as it describes a global high-resolution drought index dataset (SPEI) with direct links to data access. The `drought.gov` links also provide valuable context and direct access to SPI and other drought-related datasets.
decision_log.reasoning: Identified multiple authoritative sources (NOAA, Copernicus, drought.gov) that directly offer or describe access to high-resolution global drought indices (SPEI, SPI) and precipitation datasets (CHIRPS, CMORPH, GPCC, ERA5), which are highly relevant for drought hazard assessment. The spatial resolutions mentioned (e.g., 5km, 8km) are suitable for detailed analysis. The documents provide direct links to data catalogs or detailed descriptions of data access methods and formats (e.g., GeoTIFF, NetCDF implied by gridded data). The `No content available` documents will be skipped, and the `tandfonline.com` link appears to be a paywalled academic article, less suitable for direct data extraction.

decision_log.summary: The extracted datasets are highly relevant for drought hazard assessment, providing a variety of gridded precipitation data, drought indices (SPI, SPEI), and related water balance variables. Sources are predominantly authoritative government agencies and research institutions. The spatial and temporal resolutions are generally good, with many datasets offering global coverage and long historical records. Several datasets meet or exceed the 5km spatial resolution requirement for gridded data. The collection includes both raw precipitation data and derived drought indices, which is excellent for a comprehensive drought hazard assessment.
decision_log.reasoning: The extracted datasets are highly relevant, credible, and sufficiently complete for a global drought hazard assessment. They provide diverse and high-quality gridded data and indices that meet the specified criteria for spatial resolution (many at 5km or finer) and temporal coverage. No further deep-diving is immediately necessary for these specific datasets, as they appear ready for use in analysis.
